content: I think that if a person has a kid while already on welfare, then that person shouldn't get another dime. I know, it punishes the innocent child, but I'm tired of people breeding without restraint just to get additional benefits out of my tax dollars. People already KNOW how to use contraception. It's not rocket science, and even the dumbest high-school dropout knows how to use a rubber. The challenge is empowering women to take care of their own contraception needs, to give them the tools to educate themselves, and the promise of a world where the rewards of WORKING and EARNING a living are better than popping out kids to receive handouts and welfare. Sure, it costs a few dollars for Planned Parenthood to give out free birth control pills... but that costs a LOT LESS than years and years of welfare payments and other benefits for a low-income child. And if women who had never otherwise been given an option in life were to receive the support to seek a path other than perpetual childbearing and welfare, they might actually break the cycle. Will everyone break the cycle? Of course not. But if you take away the incentive of perpetual welfare payments, and make it more lucrative and beneficial to actually get a job and have a smaller brood of children, then hopefully more people will take that path. But the first step is strictly limiting the amount of money a person can get for being an unemployed parent. My tax dollars shouldn't support someone else's bad decisions, and perhaps even encourage those bad decisions. I work and pay taxes. That's the responsibility of every capable adult. If a person has an emergency, medical problem, or other unexpected situation, I think it's good for a civilized society to help them bridge the gap so they can become healthy, productive, or situationally stable again. If a person who has worked his entire life shatters his leg in an accident, and he works as a construction worker, he needs time to train to a new job or recover to the point where he can work again. If a person is diagnosed with cancer, then a good society helps that person while she is recovering. But if a person spends his or her lie avoiding work and responsibility, and expects to get money just for breeding... we need to stop that sort of garbage. Can we force people to stop having children? Of course not. We're not China. People have the freedom to breed. But we shouldn't fund their breeding with our tax dollars. You want kids? You support them.

content: My Mother spent most of her childhood and early adult years in Puerto Rico. She told me about a government policy there that was in effect around the 1930s or 1940s until it was reversed due to legal challenges. In those days what a couple(or single mother if that was the case) was billed for the medical services involved in delivering a baby was equivalent to one month's salary. The rich paid more, the middle class less for the same basic service. The government provided the service free of charge for those with little or no income, but there was a catch. Delivery of a second child on the government's tab included a sterilization procedure. The legal problems stemmed from the fact that the poor mothers weren't informed that they were being sterilized. I could support free government sterilizations in exchange for the free medical care, but not without prior disclosure and consent of the mother.

content: My Mother spent most of her childhood and early adult years in Puerto Rico. She told me about a government policy there that was in effect around the 1930s or 1940s until it was reversed due to legal challenges. In those days what a couple(or single mother if that was the case) was billed for the medical services involved in delivering a baby was equivalent to one month's salary. The rich paid more, the middle class less for the same basic service. The government provided the service free of charge for those with little or no income, but there was a catch. Delivery of a second child on the government's tab included a sterilization procedure. The legal problems stemmed from the fact that the poor mothers weren't informed that they were being sterilized. I could support free government sterilizations in exchange for the free medical care, but not without prior disclosure and consent of the mother.

content: My Mother spent most of her childhood and early adult years in Puerto Rico. She told me about a government policy there that was in effect around the 1930s or 1940s until it was reversed due to legal challenges. In those days what a couple(or single mother if that was the case) was billed for the medical services involved in delivering a baby was equivalent to one month's salary. The rich paid more, the middle class less for the same basic service. The government provided the service free of charge for those with little or no income, but there was a catch. Delivery of a second child on the government's tab included a sterilization procedure. The legal problems stemmed from the fact that the poor mothers weren't informed that they were being sterilized. I could support free government sterilizations in exchange for the free medical care, but not without prior disclosure and consent of the mother.

content: I think that if a person has a kid while already on welfare, then that person shouldn't get another dime. I know, it punishes the innocent child, but I'm tired of people breeding without restraint just to get additional benefits out of my tax dollars. People already KNOW how to use contraception. It's not rocket science, and even the dumbest high-school dropout knows how to use a rubber. The challenge is empowering women to take care of their own contraception needs, to give them the tools to educate themselves, and the promise of a world where the rewards of WORKING and EARNING a living are better than popping out kids to receive handouts and welfare. Sure, it costs a few dollars for Planned Parenthood to give out free birth control pills... but that costs a LOT LESS than years and years of welfare payments and other benefits for a low-income child. And if women who had never otherwise been given an option in life were to receive the support to seek a path other than perpetual childbearing and welfare, they might actually break the cycle. Will everyone break the cycle? Of course not. But if you take away the incentive of perpetual welfare payments, and make it more lucrative and beneficial to actually get a job and have a smaller brood of children, then hopefully more people will take that path. But the first step is strictly limiting the amount of money a person can get for being an unemployed parent. My tax dollars shouldn't support someone else's bad decisions, and perhaps even encourage those bad decisions. I work and pay taxes. That's the responsibility of every capable adult. If a person has an emergency, medical problem, or other unexpected situation, I think it's good for a civilized society to help them bridge the gap so they can become healthy, productive, or situationally stable again. If a person who has worked his entire life shatters his leg in an accident, and he works as a construction worker, he needs time to train to a new job or recover to the point where he can work again. If a person is diagnosed with cancer, then a good society helps that person while she is recovering. Can we force people to stop having children? Of course not. We're not China. People have the freedom to breed. But we shouldn't fund their breeding with our tax dollars. You want kids? You support them.

content: My Mother spent most of her childhood and early adult years in Puerto Rico. She told me about a government policy there that was in effect around the 1930s or 1940s until it was reversed due to legal challenges. In those days what a couple(or single mother if that was the case) was billed for the medical services involved in delivering a baby was equivalent to one month's salary. The rich paid more, the middle class less for the same basic service. The government provided the service free of charge for those with little or no income, but there was a catch. Delivery of a second child on the government's tab included a sterilization procedure. The legal problems stemmed from the fact that the poor mothers weren't informed that they were being sterilized. I could support free government sterilizations in exchange for the free medical care, but not without prior disclosure and consent of the mother.
